results.question: How is the fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets determined?
results.markdown_table_response:
The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in active markets is determined by using valuation techniques. These valuation techniques maximise the use of observable market data where it is available and rely as little as possible on entity specific estimates. If all significant inputs required for evaluating the fair value of a financial instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2.
If one or more of the significant inputs are not based on observable market data, the instrument is included in level 3.

gold_answer: on the date of his or her initial appointment to the Board of Directors equal to the pro-rated amount of the annual grant

The amount of the annual grant to a non-employee director is not subject to vesting. For example, the annual grant of $100,000 to Mr. Hill would not be subject to vesting if the value of the option was $100,000.
If a non-employee director’s annual grant amount is less than the value of an option granted, the non-employee director may be entitled to receive the annual grant amount in an amount that is equal to the amount of the annual grant minus the value of the option grant.
If a non-employee director’s annual grant amount exceeds the value of an option granted, the non-employee director may be entitled to receive the annual grant amount in an amount that is equal to the value of the option grant minus the value of the option grant.

results.question: How is Basic earnings per share, or EPS calculated?
gold_answer: by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents.
results.markdown_table_response:
Basic earnings per share is calculated by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period, without consideration for common stock equivalents. Diluted EPS is computed by dividing net income (loss) by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding for the period and the weighted-average number of dilutive common stock equivalents outstanding for the period determined using the treasury-stock method.
For the years ended December 31, 2019, 2018 and 2017, the Company incurred net losses and accordingly excluded common stock equivalents for outstanding stockbased awards, which represented all potentially dilutive securities, of 2.5 million, 3.7 million, and 4.5 million, respectively, from the calculation of diluted net loss per share due to their anti-dilutive nature.

results.question: What is the % change in the capital intensity ratio for BCE?
results.markdown_table_response:
BCE capital expenditures totaled $3,988  million for the year, up $17 million over 2018. This corresponded to a capital intensity ratio of 16.6%, down 0.3 pts compared to last year. Capital spending in the year reflected the following:
• Greater capital investments in our wireless segment of $33 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we advanced the build-out of our LTE-A network, continued to deploy wireless small-cells to expand capacity to support subscriber growth and increase network speeds, as well as to expand data fibre backhaul in preparation for 5G technology
• A modest reduction in capital spending in our wireline segment of $10 million in 2019, compared to 2018, as we continued to focus our investments on the ongoing deployment of FTTP to more homes and businesses, the roll-out of fixed WTTP to rural locations in Ontario and Québec, the connection of fibre Internet and TV services to more homes and businesses and the execution of business customer contracts
• Lower capital expenditures at Bell Media of $6 million in 2019, compared to 2018, mainly due to production equipment and IT upgrades in 2018

results.question: How is the diluted net income per share computed?
gold_answer: using the treasury stock method, for dilutive stock options, restricted stock units, and convertible notes
results.markdown_table_response:
It is computed as follows:
(1) Net income per share is calculated by dividing net income by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding during the period.
(2) Diluted net income per share is calculated using the treasury stock method, for dilutive stock options, restricted stock units, and convertible notes.
(3) Net income per share is computed as follows:
(a) Net income per share = weighted-average number of common shares outstanding +
(b) Diluted net income per share = weighted-average number of common shares outstanding -
(c) Net income per share = weighted-average number of common shares outstanding
results.csv_string_response:
The diluted net income per share is computed using the treasury stock method, for dilutive stock options, restricted stock units, and convertible notes.
The weighted-average number of common shares outstanding during the period is multiplied by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding during the period, and the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding is divided by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding. Diluted net income per share is then computed by dividing diluted net income per share by the weighted-average number of common shares outstanding.
